types.name: Query
types.description: All the available root queries.

fields.name: dbCursor
fields.description:
The most recent db cursor since the last process mutation
Cursor will be null when the db is empty.

fields.name: currentAuthor
fields.description:
The current author with publishing rights on this machine. Kinda like the "current logged
in user" on a sytem where you log in.

fields.name: thread
fields.description: Find a thread by the key string of the root message.

fields.name: threadForPost
fields.description: Find the containing thread for any post message, even if it is the root message.

fields.name: threads
fields.description:
Search for threads that match _any_ of the selectors.
Eg. if `roots_authored_by` **and** `has_replies_authored_by` are used, you will get threads
where _either_ is true. The selectors are logically OR'd, **not** AND'd.

Note that threads are conceptually ordered by time. So `first` will give you the oldest
threads first. `last` will give you the newest ones. This is how the js stack treats
ordering too, you need to `reverse` a feed to get the newest ones first.

Note that when not passing any options for `before`, `after`, `first` and `last`, the
default is to give you the most recent threads with a default `last` value of 10 threads.

args.name: before
args.description:
Use a cursor string to get results before the cursor (backwards pagination, newest
first)

args.name: after
args.description: Use a cursor string to get results after the cursor (forwards pagination, oldest first)

args.name: last
args.description: Limit the number or results to get when using `before`.

args.name: first
args.description: Limit the number or results to get when using `after`.

args.name: privacy
args.description: Find public, private or all threads.

args.name: rootsAuthoredBy
args.description: Include threads whose root message is authored by one of the provided authors

args.name: rootsAuthoredBySomeoneFollowedBy
args.description: Include threads whose root message is authored by someone followed by one of the provided authors

args.name: hasRepliesAuthoredBy
args.description: Include threads that have replies by one of the provided authors.

args.name: hasRepliesAuthoredBySomeoneFollowedBy
args.description: Include threads that have replies by someone followed by one of the provided authors.

args.name: mentionsAuthors
args.description: Include threads that mention the provided authors.

args.name: orderBy
args.description: Order threads by asserted time or received time.

fields.name: post
fields.description: Find a post by key string.

fields.name: posts
fields.description:
Search for posts that match certain filters.
Note that filters for posts are **ANDED** together. Posts meet all the conditions of the
filters to be included in the results.

Note that posts are conceptually ordered by time. So `first` will give you the oldest
threads first. `last` will give you the newest ones. This is how the js stack treats
ordering too, you need to `reverse` a feed to get the newest ones first.

Note that when not passing any options for `before`, `after`, `first` and `last`, the
default is to give you the most recent posts with a default `last` value of 10 posts.

args.name: before
args.description:
Use a cursor string to get results before the cursor (backwards pagination, newest
first)

args.name: after
args.description: Use a cursor string to get results after the cursor (forwards pagination, oldest first)

args.name: last
args.description: Limit the number or results to get when using `before`.

args.name: first
args.description: Limit the number or results to get when using `after`.

args.name: query
args.description: Find posts that match the query string.

args.name: privacy
args.description: Find public, private or all threads.

args.name: authors
args.description: Find posts that are authored by the provided authors.

args.name: mentionsAuthors
args.description: Find posts that mention the provided authors.

args.name: orderBy
args.description: Find posts that mention the provided channels.

fields.name: author
fields.description: Find an author by their public key string.

fields.name: authors
fields.description: Search for an author by a query string. Will search names and optionally descriptions too.

fields.name: messageTypes
fields.description: Find all the message types we know about

fields.name: messagesByType
fields.description: Find all messages by type

fields.name: message
fields.description: Find a message by key string

fields.name: links
fields.description: Search for links from or to a message id

types.name: String
types.description: The `String` scalar type represents textual data, represented as UTF-8 character sequences. The String type is most often used by GraphQL to represent free-form human-readable text.

types.name: Author
types.description: The author of a feed.

fields.name: name
fields.description: The self assigned name of the author, if given.

fields.name: description
fields.description: The self assigned description of the author, if given.

fields.name: imageLink
fields.description: The self assigned image_link of the author, if given.

fields.name: id
fields.description: The public key of the author on the SSB network.

fields.name: contactStatusTo
fields.description: The author's relationship toward another author. Eg, Does this author block the other?

fields.name: contactStatusFrom
fields.description: Another author's relationship toward this author. Eg, do they block this author?

fields.name: follows
fields.description: The authors that this author follows.

fields.name: blocks
fields.description: The authors that this author blocks.

fields.name: followedBy
fields.description: Other authors that follow this author.

fields.name: blockedBy
fields.description: Other authors that block this author.

types.name: PublicPrivateContactStatus
types.description:
An author's Public and Private contact states.
Author's may publish private block and follow messages only visible to themselves.
This means that the app's user can see their own private contact messages, but not anyone
else's.

fields.name: private
fields.description: Encrypted contact state, availble only to this app's user.

fields.name: public
fields.description: Publically published contact state

types.name: ContactState
types.description: An author's relationship with another author.

enumValues.name: BLOCK
enumValues.description: Blocking means an author does not want to see another's messages or replicate their feed.

enumValues.name: FOLLOW
enumValues.description: Following means an author wants to see another's messages, and replicate their feed.

enumValues.name: NEUTRAL
enumValues.description: Neutral means they have not followed or blocked an author.

types.name: OrderBy
types.description: Retrieve objects ordered by asserted publish time or by received time

enumValues.name: ASSERTED
enumValues.description:
Order by asserted timestamp (the time the author claimed they published the message).

Note that using asserted timestamp is not reliable. If the publisher of a message has their
system clock set incorrectly then this can really break your ui. This has already happened
before on the network.

enumValues.name: RECEIVED
enumValues.description:
Order by received timestamp (the time that the message was inserted into your db).

Note that using received timestamp does not work well when the db has downloaded many feeds
all at once (like during onboarding to the network) because feeds are inserted into your db
in a random order.

types.name: Thread
types.description: A thread of posts. Threads have a root post and a collection of reply posts.

fields.name: root
fields.description: The root (intitial) post.

fields.name: replies
fields.description:
The reply posts.
The replies are sorted by causal ordering based on which messages reference other messages.

fields.name: isPrivate
fields.description: Whether or not the messages are encrypted.

types.name: Post
types.description: A post by an author. Posts may contain text / images etc. Same idea as a facebook / twitter post

fields.name: id
fields.description: The globally unique identifier of this post, derived from the hash of this message.

fields.name: author
fields.description: The author of this post.

fields.name: likes
fields.description: The likes other authors have published about this post.

fields.name: likedByMe
fields.description: Whether this post is liked by me.

fields.name: likesCount
fields.description: The number of likes on this post.

fields.name: assertedTimestamp
fields.description:
The asserted timestamp of the post.
Asserted means that it's the time the author claims that they published the message.
You can't totally trust this value, the author may have their clock set wrong, be in a
different timezone, or they might be deliberately setting an incorrect published time for
some reason, eg. to prevent leaking meta-data.

fields.name: receivedTimestamp
fields.description:
The received timestamp of the post.
This is the time that the message was inserted into your db on this machine.
You know that a message cannot have been published any later than the received timestamp.
**BUT** you can't tell if the message was originally published 5 seconds or 5 years before it was
inserted into your database. This **can happen** eg when an author comes into your follow
range but has been on the network for a long time and you download their entire feed in one
go.

fields.name: text
fields.description: The text body of the post.

fields.name: forksFromKey
fields.description:
If this post forks from another discussion, the forksFromKey is the id of the message
that it forks from.

fields.name: rootKey
fields.description:
If this post is a part of a thread then the root_key is the id of the messsage that started
the thread.

fields.name: references
fields.description: Any other messages outside this thread that link / reference this one.

fields.name: forks
fields.description: Any other threads that have forked from this one.

types.name: Like
types.description: A like or vote published about a certain message.

fields.name: author
fields.description: The author of the like

fields.name: value
fields.description: The integer value of the like, may be positive or negative.

types.name: Int
types.description: The `Int` scalar type represents non-fractional signed whole numeric values. Int can represent values between -(2^31) and 2^31 - 1.

types.name: Boolean
types.description: The `Boolean` scalar type represents `true` or `false`.

types.name: Float
types.description: The `Float` scalar type represents signed double-precision fractional values as specified by [IEEE 754](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IEEE_floating_point).

types.name: Privacy
types.description: Retrieve objects that are private, public, or both.

enumValues.name: ALL
enumValues.description: Both public and private.

enumValues.name: PRIVATE
enumValues.description: Only private.

enumValues.name: PUBLIC
enumValues.description: Only public.

types.name: ThreadConnection
types.description: Connection to collections of threads

fields.name: edges
fields.description: The edges in this connection

fields.name: pageInfo
fields.description: The relay-spec pageInfo for this connection

fields.name: totalCount
fields.description: The total count of posts in this connection.

types.name: ThreadEdge
types.description: Edge connection to a thread

fields.name: node
fields.description: The nodes in this connection

fields.name: cursor
fields.description: The cursor for this node

types.name: PageInfo
types.description: A relay-spec PageInfo object used for pagination of queries.

fields.name: hasNextPage
fields.description: Is there a next page available to read?

fields.name: hasPreviousPage
fields.description: Is there a previous page available to read?

fields.name: endCursor
fields.description: The cursor for the last item in the page.

fields.name: startCursor
fields.description: The cursor for the first item in the page.

types.name: PostConnection
types.description: Connection to collections of posts

fields.name: totalCount
fields.description: The total count of posts in this connection.

fields.name: edges
fields.description: The nodes in this connection

fields.name: pageInfo
fields.description: The relay-spec pageInfo for this connection

types.name: PostEdge
types.description: Edge connection to a post

fields.name: node
fields.description: The nodes in this connection

fields.name: cursor
fields.description: The cursor for this node

types.name: DbMutation
types.description: Mutations available to change the state of the db

fields.name: process
fields.description:
This db will lag behind the offset log and needs calls to `process` to bring the db up to
date. At first this might seem annoying and that the db should do this automatically. But
this is a conscious design decision to give the app control of when cpu is used. This is
very important on resource constrained devices, or even just when starting up the app. This
is a major pain point in the javascript flume-db implementation that we're avoiding by
doing this.

types.name: ProcessResults
types.description:
The result of running a process mutation, giving the number of messages processed (the
chunkSize) and the new lastest flume_sequence. TBD if the flume seq should just be an opaque
cursor.

fields.name: chunkSize
fields.description:
The number of entries inserted into the db (although not all of them will be useful to the
application)

fields.name: latestSequence
fields.description:
The most recent sequence number processed from the offset log. The offset log is the source
of truth that this db is built off. This is unlikely to be used by an application and may
be removed in the future.

types.name: __Schema
types.description: A GraphQL Schema defines the capabilities of a GraphQL server. It exposes all available types and directives on the server, as well as the entry points for query, mutation, and subscription operations.

fields.name: types
fields.description: A list of all types supported by this server.

fields.name: queryType
fields.description: The type that query operations will be rooted at.

fields.name: mutationType
fields.description: If this server supports mutation, the type that mutation operations will be rooted at.

fields.name: subscriptionType
fields.description: If this server support subscription, the type that subscription operations will be rooted at.

fields.name: directives
fields.description: A list of all directives supported by this server.

types.name: __Type
types.description:
The fundamental unit of any GraphQL Schema is the type. There are many kinds of types in GraphQL as represented by the `__TypeKind` enum.

Depending on the kind of a type, certain fields describe information about that type. Scalar types provide no information beyond a name and description, while Enum types provide their values. Object and Interface types provide the fields they describe. Abstract types, Union and Interface, provide the Object types possible at runtime. List and NonNull types compose other types.

types.name: __TypeKind
types.description: An enum describing what kind of type a given `__Type` is.

enumValues.name: SCALAR
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a scalar.

enumValues.name: OBJECT
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an object. `fields` and `interfaces` are valid fields.

enumValues.name: INTERFACE
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an interface. `fields` and `possibleTypes` are valid fields.

enumValues.name: UNION
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a union. `possibleTypes` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: ENUM
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an enum. `enumValues` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: INPUT_OBJECT
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an input object. `inputFields` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: LIST
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a list. `ofType` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: NON_NULL
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a non-null. `ofType` is a valid field.

types.name: __Field
types.description: Object and Interface types are described by a list of Fields, each of which has a name, potentially a list of arguments, and a return type.

types.name: __InputValue
types.description: Arguments provided to Fields or Directives and the input fields of an InputObject are represented as Input Values which describe their type and optionally a default value.

fields.name: defaultValue
fields.description: A GraphQL-formatted string representing the default value for this input value.

types.name: __EnumValue
types.description: One possible value for a given Enum. Enum values are unique values, not a placeholder for a string or numeric value. However an Enum value is returned in a JSON response as a string.

types.name: __Directive
types.description:
A Directive provides a way to describe alternate runtime execution and type validation behavior in a GraphQL document.

In some cases, you need to provide options to alter GraphQL's execution behavior in ways field arguments will not suffice, such as conditionally including or skipping a field. Directives provide this by describing additional information to the executor.

types.name: __DirectiveLocation
types.description: A Directive can be adjacent to many parts of the GraphQL language, a __DirectiveLocation describes one such possible adjacencies.

enumValues.name: QUERY
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a query operation.

enumValues.name: MUTATION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a mutation operation.

enumValues.name: SUBSCRIPTION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a subscription operation.

enumValues.name: FIELD
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a field.

enumValues.name: FRAGMENT_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a fragment definition.

enumValues.name: FRAGMENT_SPREAD
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a fragment spread.

enumValues.name: INLINE_FRAGMENT
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an inline fragment.

enumValues.name: VARIABLE_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a variable definition.

enumValues.name: SCHEMA
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a schema definition.

enumValues.name: SCALAR
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a scalar definition.

enumValues.name: OBJECT
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an object type definition.

enumValues.name: FIELD_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a field definition.

enumValues.name: ARGUMENT_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an argument definition.

enumValues.name: INTERFACE
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an interface definition.

enumValues.name: UNION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a union definition.

enumValues.name: ENUM
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an enum definition.

enumValues.name: ENUM_VALUE
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an enum value definition.

enumValues.name: INPUT_OBJECT
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an input object type definition.

enumValues.name: INPUT_FIELD_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an input object field definition.
